The_Wagoneers:
{{Short description|American neo-traditional country music band}}
'''The Wagoneers''' are a neo-traditional country band founded in [[Austin, Texas]] in 1986 and now enjoying a resurgence. As innovators who attracted critical acclaim with a fresh, high-energy interpretation of a historical country sound—part honky-tonk and part rockabilly—The Wagoneers influenced other artists and helped lay the foundation for the emerging Americana and alt-country movement of the 1990s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/the-wagoneers-roll-again/|title=The Wagoneers Roll Again|last=Smith|first=William Michael|date=March–April 2011|volume=4 – Issue 2|work=Lone Star Music Magazine|access-date=2019-09-29}}</ref>{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->

The original line-up included bandleader and songwriter Monte Warden (lead vocals, rhythm guitar), Brent Wilson (lead guitar, backing vocals), Craig Allan Pettigrew (bass) and Thomas A. Lewis, Jr. (drums).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-wagoneers-mn0000582550/biography|title=The Wagoneers|last=Pendragon|first=Jana|date=|website=|publisher=All Music|access-date=6 December 2016}}</ref>  The band performed, toured, and recorded two albums in 1988 and 1989 before disbanding. It reformed about 22 years later in 2012 and continues to play regularly in Austin and regionally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2017-06-30/margaret-moser-tribute-monte-warden-monte-warden/|title=Margaret Moser Tribute: Monte Warden|last1=Curtin|first1=Kevin|website=www.austinchronicle.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-29|date=June 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.songwritingwithsoldiers.org/the-songwriters/monte-warden/|title=SongwritingWith:Soldiers » Monte Warden|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-29}}</ref>

==Background==
The Wagoneers performed at the very first SXSW music festival in 1987. The  band was soon signed to [[A&M Records]]. Their debut album, ''Stout and High,'' was released on A&M in 1988; a follow-up album, ''Good Fortune,'' was released in 1989. The band performed internationally during this era, including appearances on ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' and ''[[Nashville Now]],'' and The Grand Ole Opry.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.steamiron.com/twangin/int-warden.html|title=Twangin'! Interview - Monte Warden|website=www.steamiron.com}}</ref>

Its debut album, “Stout and High,” proved influential. It received a positive critical reception, earning the band awards; singles from the album enjoyed national radio play. Chet Flippo (''Rolling Stone'') characterized The Wagoneers as "The greatest honky tonk band that ever was." Margaret Moser (''Austin Chronicle'') referred to them as "The fathers of alt-country and Americana." Bob Oermann (''Music Row Magazine'') referred to The Wagoneers as "The band that started the modern Texas Music scene." Mario Tarradell (''Dallas Morning News'') called them, "A mythic and legendary band." ''Billboard'' stated, “If The Clash had been a country band, they would have been The Wagoneers.”<ref>Quotes from reviews retrieved from personal archive of Monte and Brandi Warden in Austin, TX, Sept. 27, 2019</ref>

The band toured and attracted crowds while sharing the stage with diverse acts. Including bands with whom Monte Warden played as a solo artist, these include headliners Willie Nelson, Emmylou Harris, George Strait, Roger Miller, Bill Monroe, Rank and File, Joe Ely, Kelly Willis, Bruce Robison, Marty Stuart, The Mavericks, Justin Furstenfeld (Blue October), Dwight Yoakam, The Ramones, Patty Loveless, Radney Foster, Vince Gill, Soul Asylum, John Hiatt, Chuck Berry, ZZ Top, Stevie Ray Vaughan, The Who, Randy Travis, Miranda Lambert, Lyle Lovett, and kd lang.<ref>Interview with Monte Warden; review of performance documentation in Warden’s personal archive.  September 27, 2019</ref>

By 1991 the group had disbanded and the members pursued separate careers. (During Monte Warden's solo career, his backing band, The Lonesharks, included three musicians in the current line-up of The Wagoneers: guitarist Brent Wilson, bassist Brad Fordham, drummer/co-producer Mas Palermo. In 1994 they were named the "Best Roots Rock" band at the Austin Music Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/performers/479612/|title=Austin Music Awards 1994|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>)

For its 2011 induction into Austin Music Awards Hall of Fame<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/austin-music-awards/year:2010/category:hall-of-fame/1163991/|title=The Wagoneers - Winner - Austin Music Awards - 2010 - Hall of Fame - The Austin Chronicle|website=www.austinchronicle.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-29}}</ref> (aka The Texas Music Hall of Fame), The Wagoneers reunited for an awards show performance, reformed, and began performing again. They put out a CD that re-issued both of their first albums in a compilation as "The Essential Wagoneers (2011)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2011-04-29/the-wagoneers-the-essential-wagoneers/|title=The Wagoneers: The Essential Wagoneers Album Review|last1=Moser|first1=Margaret|website=www.austinchronicle.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-09-29|date=April 29, 2011}}</ref> The band has recorded a new album with Grammy-winning and multi-platinum producer, Mark Bright, at the helm; it awaits release. The first band ever signed from SXSW, The Wagoneers again have appeared as an official SXSW showcase in recent years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/TheWagoneers/photos/a.1694654524115621/1839516272962778/?type=3&theater|title=The Wagoneers, SXSW showcase 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Facebook]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>

The Wagoneers play regularly at legendary Texas live music venues with popular dance floors. Venues for their weekly or monthly residencies (standing gigs) have included The Continental Club, The Saxon Pub, C-Boys Heart and Soul, The Mucky Duck, and the historic Austin dance hall, The Broken Spoke.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brokenspokeaustintx.net/events-calendar|title=The Broken Spoke - Events Calendar|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/TheWagoneers/|title=Facebook page for The Wagoneers|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Facebook]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>

The Wagoneers were among hundreds of artists whose material was destroyed in the [[2008 Universal fire]].<ref>{{cite tweet|number=1143999815669473285|user=MonteWarden1|title=@jodyrosen as an artist who lost 30+ masters in the 2008 UMG fire (as The Wagoneers) let me plz thank you for your…<!-- full text of tweet that Twitter returned to the bot (excluding links) added by TweetCiteBot. This may be better truncated or may need expanding (TW limits responses to 140 characters) or case changes. --> |date=26 June 2019}}</ref>
